title: Two Charged Spheres Very Far Apart

content.question: This question is a long free-response question. Show your work for each part of the question. (15 points, suggested time 25 minutes) The figure above shows two conducting spheres that are very far apart. The spheres have the same radius <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and the different negative charges shown. Outside the spheres, the charge on each sphere can be treated as if it were at the center of the sphere. (a) Compare the magnitude of the electric field at the surface of sphere A to the magnitude of the electric field at the surface of sphere B. Justify your answer.

frqParts.text: This question is a long free-response question. Show your work for each part of the question. (15 points, suggested time 25 minutes) The figure above shows two conducting spheres that are very far apart. The spheres have the same radius <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and the different negative charges shown. Outside the spheres, the charge on each sphere can be treated as if it were at the center of the sphere. (a) Compare the magnitude of the electric field at the surface of sphere A to the magnitude of the electric field at the surface of sphere B. Justify your answer.

Consider two scenarios, one in which an individual electron is moved from far away to a position outside one of the spheres at a distance <math alttext="d" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> from the surface, and the other in which an individual proton is moved in the same manner.(b) An external force must do non-zero work to move each particle to the distance <math alttext="d" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Indicate whether the sign of the work is the same for both the electron and the proton. Justify your answer using the concepts of electric fields or forces.

(c) Compare the magnitude of the work required to move an electron to a distance <math alttext="d" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> from the surface of sphere A to the magnitude of the work required to move an electron to a distance <math alttext="d" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> from the surface of sphere B. Justify your answer using the concepts of electric fields or forces.

(d) When an electron with charge of magnitude e is brought from far away to a distance d from the center of one of the spheres, the electron-sphere system experiences a change in potential energy of magnitude <math alttext="delta U" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>U</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. The equation for this change is <math alttext="delta U equals, the fraction with numerator k times e, times Q, and denominator d" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>U</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>k</mi><mi>e</mi><mi>Q</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="k equals, the fraction with numerator 1, and denominator 4 pi times epsilon sub 0, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>k</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn><mi>π</mi><msub><mrow><mi>ε</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>. Use this equation to compare the magnitude of the change in potential energy of the electron-sphere A system to that of the electron-sphere B system when the electron is brought from far away to a distance <math alttext="d" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> from the center of each sphere. Explain your reasoning.
(e) Is your answer from part (d) consistent with your answer from part (c)? Justify your answer using physics principles.

Two point charges, F and G, have the charges shown in the figure above. Each charge is a distance <math alttext="L" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> from point <math alttext="P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. The electric field at point <math alttext="P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> due to charge F has magnitude <math alttext="E sub F" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>E</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. (f) Describe the magnitude and direction of the net electric field at point <math alttext="P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> due to both charges in terms of <math alttext="E sub F" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>E</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and with respect to the coordinate axes shown. If the net electric field is not directed along an axis, indicate to which axis the direction of the net electric field is closest. If the direction of the net electric field is exactly in the middle (<math alttext="45 degrees" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>45</mn><mi>°</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> from each axis), state this explicitly. Explain your reasoning using relevant physics principles.
(g) The diagrams shown above depict isolines of electric potential. Which diagram best depicts the isolines of electric potential of charges F and G? Explain your reasoning.
